item.title: [PDFBOX-2373] Rendering at 72 dpi crashes java
item.description: Rendering the attached file crashes java. It happens only at 72 dpi. It can be reproduced with the PDFToImage cmd app, not with PDFReader.

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

I get a crash on JDK 1.7 but not 1.6, the crash report on OS X looks like a stack overflow due to recursive calls to "processCubic" in "libdcpr.dylib", which would appear to be this JVM bug: https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-6996336

Problem seems to be due to dashed lines?
I've edited my text above to include the last dash pattern.

jens@jens-S4216:~/Downloads$ java -jar pdfbox-app-2.0.0-20150204.221116-1029.jar PDFToImage -resolution 72 "228-228597-p19-crash.pdf"

WARNUNG: No Unicode mapping for A0 (2) in font T2

java version "1.8.0_20"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_20-b26)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.20-b23, mixed mode)

I'm closing this as "won't fix". There's nothing we can do, sadly. It happens with ordinary java calls with ordinary parameter values. There is an excellent bug report at oracle and they don't fix it. It works with OpenJDK.

The values in the dash array aren't particularly "ordinary", they're tiny fractions of a pixel:

[0.119, 0.024, 0.024, 0.024]

Acrobat renders these as solid lines unless zoom is 3000%. We already enforce a minimum line width of .25px in getStroke(), doing the same here might avoid this crash.

Commit 1657690 from jahewson in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1657690 ]

PDFBOX-2373: Use minimum line width for dash patterns to avoid JVM crash
I no longer get a JVM crash, how about you guys?
Although it works for me, my rendering regression tests show differences on several files (at least 13). I'll make tests with lower thresholds.

I tested with 0.016 (it crashed at 0.015 with 72dpi). My regression tests run with 96dpi. Setting a lower number than yours doesn't make the differences go away, but it seems to minimize them somewhat. In other words: even if these numbers look like "a fraction of a pixel", changing them does have an impact. That is why I'm setting that (lower) number.

The following files have differences: gs-bugzilla691715.pdf, gs-bugzilla691716.pdf, gs-bugzilla694310.pdf, PDFBOX-1094-094730.pdf p4, PDFBOX-1620.pdf, PDFBOX-1691-FORIS-HV.pdf p13+14, PDFBOX-1824.pdf, PDFBOX-2055.pdf p1-5.

Commit 1657760 from tilman in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1657760 ]

PDFBOX-2373: set lower threshhold in order to minimize differences

In other words: even if these numbers look like "a fraction of a pixel", changing them does have an impact.

Yep, you're going to see rounding effects, so if you have 0.484 + 0.016 then it's enough to get a 1/2 pixel which will alter the anti-aliasing. Actually a 1/4 pixel would be enough to do this. Technically PDF doesn't provide sub-pixel accuracy because of its scan line model, but Java2D doesn't work in the same way.

The lowest values which work are likely to be the best for our rendering needs.
